contextId.information: This is a sign of humble respect before Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This is a way someone would show respect in Jewish culture. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"shake the dust off your feet as you leave." This is a sign that God has rejected the people of that house or city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: shake off the dust from your feet

contextId.information: This shows that the woman is humbling herself before Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This shows that the servant approached the king in the most humble way possible. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

This shows that the servant approached the king in the most humble way possible. See how you translated these phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:18:26|18:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
Tearing clothing was a sign of anger and sadness. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: the high priest tore his clothes

contextId.information: Pilate does this as a sign that he is not responsible for Jesus' death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
contextId.quote: washed his hands in front of the crowd
